The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed. The three clauses of a for statement are the: 1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter. 2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body. 3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body. 4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines. explanation:
Only the two for statements in update_directory are relevant to MISRA C:2023 Rule 14.2. They initialize a single loop counter in the first clause, use that counter in the second clause (a sentinel check against a NULL terminator) and increment only that counter in the third clause. No other for loops appear in the provided code. The other code fragments do not need investigation under Rule 14.2 because:
- list_directory uses a while loop (not subject to this for-loop rule).
- There are no visible modifications of language_idx or category_idx inside their loop bodies (no assignments to those identifiers, and called functions do not operate on the languages/categories arrays or those index variables).
- The second clauses are simple sentinel checks that have no persistent side effects and do not reference objects that are modified in the respective loop bodies.
- The third clauses perform a single increment of the loop counter only.
Therefore only the two for headers listed above should be investigated for any subtle issues (e.g. hidden aliasing or side-effects in functions called from the body).
